facts.text: Civil Appeal No.130 of 1958 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.130 of 1958. Appeal by certificate granted by the Madras High Court

facts.text: Appeal by certificate granted by Madras High Court against its judgment dated November 1, 1957 in W. Nos. 623 and 624 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate granted by the Madras High Court against its judgment and order dated November 1, 1957, in W. Nos. 623 and 624 of 1957.

facts.text: 1957 general elections held for Madras Legislative Assembly from Sathankulam constituency.

anchor.surface_text: In the 1957 general elections, nine persons filed nomination papers for election to the Madras Legislative Assembly from the Sathankulam constituency all of which were found on scrutiny to be valid.

facts.text: Nine persons filed nomination papers for Sathankulam constituency, all valid on scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: In the 1957 general elections, nine persons filed nomination papers for election to the Madras Legislative Assembly from the Sathankulam constituency all of which were found on scrutiny to be valid.

facts.text: Candidates included appellant, respondent Kandaswami, R. Meganathan and G. E. Muthu.

anchor.surface_text: Among these persons were the appellant, the respondent Kandaswami and two others called R. Meganathan and G. E. Muthu.

facts.text: Meganathan, Muthu and three others dropped out before the poll.

anchor.surface_text: Meganathan, Muthu and three others whom it is not necessary to name as they are not concerned with this appeal, did not go to the poll and dropped out of the election earlier.

facts.text: Election contested by appellant, respondent Kandaswami and two other candidates.

anchor.surface_text: At the end the election was actually contested by the appellant, the respondent Kandaswami and two other candidates with whom also this appeal is not concerned.

facts.text: Appellant declared elected on March 6, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was successful at the poll and was on March 6,1957, declared elected.

facts.text: Respondent Kandaswami filed election petition on April 15, 1957 under Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On April 15, 1957, the respondent Kandaswami whom we will hereafter refer to as the respondent, preferred an election petition under the provisions of the Representation of the People Act, 1951,

facts.text: Appellant made first respondent to the election petition; Meganathan and Muthu not made parties.

anchor.surface_text: for a declaration that the election of the appellant was void. The appellant was made the first respondent to the petition but Meganathan and Muthu were not made parties to it at all.

facts.text: Election petition referred to Election Tribunal for trial.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was referred to an Election Tribunal for trial.

facts.text: Appellant filed I.A. No.1 of 1957 before Tribunal for dismissal of petition under s.90(3) for non-compliance with s.82.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then made an application to the Election Tribunal which was marked I. A. No. 1 of 1957 for the dismissal of the petition under s. 90(3) of the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal dismissed appellant's application.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal accepted the contention of the respondent and dismissed the application of the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant filed applications in Madras High Court for certiorari and prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the High Court at Madras by two applications, one for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the, order of the Tribunal dismissing his application and the other for the issue of a writ of prohibition

facts.text: Madras High Court dismissed both applications on November 1, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its judgment dated November 1, 1957, dismissed both the applications, taking the same view as the Tribunal.

facts.text: Meganathan and Muthu were candidates as defined in s.79 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that Meganathan and Muthu were candidates. A candidate has been defined in s. 79 of the Act as meaning among others,

facts.text: Election petition alleged first respondent (appellant) and agent paid Rs.10,000 gift to Meganathan to withdraw from Sathankulam, and he withdrew.

anchor.surface_text: Sri M. R. Meganathan was candidate for Sattankulam and Tiruchandur Assembly Constituencies at the election. The first respondent and his election Agent paid him a gift of Rs. 10,000 to induce him to withdraw from being a candidate at the election from Sattankulam Constituency and in pursuance thereof Sri M. R. Meganathan withdrew his candidature

facts.text: Election petition alleged first respondent (appellant) and agent paid Rs.5,000 gratification to Muthu to retire from contest, and he retired.

anchor.surface_text: One Sri G. E. Muthu, candidate at the election in this Constituency was paid a gratification of Rs. 5,000 by the first respondent and his Election Agent for the purpose of making him retire from contest and in pursuance thereof he retired on the contest

facts.text: Appellant contended that allegations of corrupt practice made against Meganathan and Muthu, so they should be parties under s.82(b).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended that allegations of corrupt practice were made in the petition against Meganathan and Muthu and they should, therefore, have been made parties to the petition under s. 82

facts.text: Respondent contended no allegation of corrupt practice against Meganathan or Muthu.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents answer to the application was that no allegation of corrupt practice had been made in the petition against Meganathan or Muthu.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered by SARKAR J. on May 20, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. May 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.-

facts.text: Non-compliance with s.82 entails dismissal of election petition.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that non-compliance with the provisions of s. 82 entails the dismissal of an election petition.

issues.text: The only question that arises in this appeal is whether allegations of corrupt practice are made against them [Meganathan and Muthu] in the election petition

anchor.surface_text: The only question that arises in this appeal is whether allegations of corrupt practice are made against them in the election petition.

issues.text: Is an allegation that a candidate accepted money paid to him to induce him to drop out of the election contest and actually so dropped out, an allegation of corrupt practice against such a candidate?

anchor.surface_text: So all that is said here against Meganathan and Muthu and we are concerned only with allegations against them- is that they accepted money paid to them to induce them to abandon the contest and actually abandoned the contest. Is an allegation then, that a candidate accepted money

issues.text: Is an acceptance of a bribe a corrupt practice within the definition of bribery in section 123(1)?

anchor.surface_text: is an acceptance of a bribe, by which word we mean a gift made with the intention specified, a corrupt practice within this definition ? We do not think it is. What this definition makes the corrupt practice of bribery is a gift, offer or promise by a candidate or his agent

holdings.text: We are in agreement with this view [that an allegation of acceptance of bribe is not an allegation of corrupt practice against the candidate].

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that it was not and that only the giving of a bribe was a corrupt practice and not an acceptance of it. We are in agreement with this view. he Act contemplates various kinds of corrupt practices

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreeing with High Court; acceptance not constituting corrupt practice allegation under s.82(b).

holdings.text: We do not think it is [acceptance of a bribe is a corrupt practice within this definition]. What this definition makes the corrupt practice of bribery is a gift, offer or promise by a candidate or his agent or by any other person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.123(1): corrupt practice is the act of gift/offer/promise, not acceptance.

holdings.text: By omitting s. 124(3) from the Act therefore the legislature intended that acceptance of a bribe was no longer to be treated as a corrupt practice.

anchor.surface_text: That s. 123(1) does not contemplate the acceptance of a gift to be a corrupt practice is also apparent from a consideration of s. 124 of the Act which was deleted by an amendment made by Act XXVII of 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative history: deletion of s.124(3) without amending s.123(1) shows intent to exclude acceptance.

holdings.text: Section 99 does not purport to define a corrupt practice. [...] A corrupt practice committed with the consent of a candidate is not in itself a new kind of corrupt practice. [...] the consent by a candidate to the commission of a corrupt practice by some one else [...] is not itself a corrupt practice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.99 refers to s.123-defined CPs; consent not a separate CP requiring joinder under s.82(b).

holdings.text: We are wholly unable to agree that the withdrawal of his candidature by a candidate to induce another candidate to stand at an election would be gratification within s. 123.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri then said that the term gratification in s. 123 was very wide and would include the withdrawal of his candidature by a candidate to induce another candidate to stand at an election. He contended that the affording

holdings.reasoning_summary: Withdrawal of candidature does not qualify as 'gratification' under s.123 definition.

holdings.text: when s. 82(b) talks of allegations of corrupt practice against a candidate it means allegations that a candidate has committed a corrupt practice. Allegations can hardly be said to be against one unless they impute some default to him. So allegations of corrupt practice against a candidate must mean that the candidate was guilty of corrupt practice.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, Mr. Sastri contended that s. 82(b) talked of allegations of any corrupt practice and it therefore contemplated any allegation relating to or concerning, a corrupt practice. He said that the election petition contained

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.82(b) requires joinder only for candidates alleged to have committed CP, imputing default.

holdings.text: It was therefore not necessary to make Meganathan and Muthu parties to the petition under s. 82(b).

anchor.surface_text: But assume it is so. That does not help the appellant at all. Here, there is no allegation in the petition that Meganathan and Muthu withdrew their candidature in order to induce the appellant to stand at the election,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: no CP allegation against them, so no non-compliance with s.82, no dismissal under s.90(3).

holdings.text: The corrupt practice consists in the giving of the gift and not in the acceptance of it.
